title: MOG Antibody Disease (MOGAD)
scope: ** Diagnosis, acute treatment, relapse prevention, and long-term monitoring of MOG antibody disease (MOGAD). Covers MOG-IgG testing and interpretation, clinical phenotypes (optic neuritis, transverse myelitis, ADEM-like presentations, brainstem/cerebellar syndromes), differentiation from MS and NMOSD (AQP4), acute attack treatment (IV methylprednisolone, IVIG, PLEX), slow oral steroid taper, maintenance immunotherapy (IVIG, azathioprine, mycophenolate, rituximab), monophasic vs relapsing disease course, and serial MOG-IgG titer monitoring. Excludes AQP4-positive NMOSD (use "NMOSD" template) and MS (use "MS - New Diagnosis" template).

Inflammatory/vasculitis screen; systemic autoimmune disease evaluation

Differentiation: AQP4-positive NMOSD has different treatment and prognosis; dual-positive (MOG+/AQP4+) is extremely rare -- retest if occurs
Lupus cerebritis and systemic autoimmune disease screen
Low levels associated with demyelinating disease activity
Neurosyphilis causes optic neuropathy and myelopathy

Neurosarcoidosis causes optic neuropathy and myelopathy

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Screen before rituximab; reactivation risk with B-cell depletion

Atypical features or poor treatment response; optic neuropathy/myelopathy with occult malignancy
Stiff-person spectrum; autoimmune cerebellar ataxia; overlap evaluation
CNS vasculitis (granulomatosis with polyangiitis causes pachymeningitis, optic neuropathy)

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24h if acute; within 2 weeks if stable
Essential/First-line.target: Fluffy/ill-defined T2/FLAIR white matter lesions; deep gray matter involvement; thalamic lesions (ADEM-like); cortical lesions; absent Dawson fingers (unlike MS)

Essential/First-line.item: MRI orbits with and without contrast and fat suppression (CPT 70543)

Essential/First-line.item: MRI C-spine with and without contrast (CPT 72156)
Essential/First-line.target: Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (LETM >=3 segments); central/H-sign cord lesion; conus medullaris involvement

Essential/First-line.item: MRI T-spine with and without contrast (CPT 72157)

Disease-Modifying / Maintenance Therapie.indication: First-line maintenance immunotherapy for relapsing MOGAD; strongest evidence base among maintenance options; reduces relapse rate and steroid dependence

dosing.instructions: 0.4-2 g/kg IV every 4-6 weeks; typical starting dose 1 g/kg monthly; adjust dose/interval based on relapse frequency and trough IgG levels

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology (neuroimmunology) consult for diagnosis confirmation, antibody interpretation, and immunotherapy management
Neuro-ophthalmology evaluation for optic neuritis severity assessment, visual field testing, and OCT baseline
Ophthalmology urgent evaluation for visual acuity assessment and fundoscopic examination if optic neuritis suspected
Physical therapy for gait training, balance assessment, and fall prevention given myelitis-related weakness
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, adaptive equipment, and energy conservation strategies
Speech-language pathology for swallowing evaluation if brainstem involvement or bulbar symptoms present
Urology for neurogenic bladder management if urinary retention or refractory urgency from myelitis
Pain management referral for refractory neuropathic pain not responding to first-line agents
Psychiatry if depression, anxiety, or adjustment disorder from chronic illness requiring treatment
Social work for insurance navigation, disability resources, and infusion center coordination for maintenance IVIG
Pulmonology if respiratory compromise from high cervical myelitis requiring ventilatory support assessment
Rehabilitation medicine for comprehensive inpatient rehabilitation program if significant residual deficits
Infusion center coordination for outpatient IVIG maintenance therapy scheduling and monitoring
Pediatric neurology referral if ADEM-like presentation in child (MOGAD is more common in children than adults)

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately for new or worsening vision loss, new weakness, numbness, or bladder/bowel dysfunction (may indicate new attack or relapse)
Do NOT stop oral prednisone abruptly -- rapid steroid taper causes high relapse risk in MOGAD and may cause adrenal crisis
Report any new visual changes immediately including blurred vision, eye pain with movement, or color desaturation (may indicate optic neuritis relapse)
Do NOT drive until visual acuity and visual fields have been formally assessed and cleared by ophthalmology/neuro-ophthalmology
MOGAD is a treatable condition -- most patients recover well from attacks, especially with early and aggressive treatment
Report any signs of infection (fever >100.4F, cough, dysuria, rash) immediately while on immunosuppressive therapy
Avoid live vaccines while on immunosuppressive therapy; inform all healthcare providers of immunosuppressed status
Keep an attack diary documenting new symptoms, dates, and steroid dose at time of relapse to guide treatment decisions
Pregnancy planning must be discussed with neurology before conception; some maintenance therapies are teratogenic
IVIG infusions must not be skipped or delayed without neurology approval; missed infusions increase relapse risk
Medical alert bracelet recommended (MOGAD, immunosuppressed, steroid-dependent)
Follow-up with neurology within 1-2 weeks after acute attack treatment to assess response and plan taper/maintenance

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Vitamin D supplementation (2000-4000 IU daily) to maintain levels >30 ng/mL given association between low vitamin D and demyelinating disease activity
Smoking cessation to reduce vascular risk and potential inflammatory disease activity
Low-sodium diet during steroid therapy to reduce fluid retention, hypertension, and weight gain
Calcium supplementation (1000-1200 mg daily) during prolonged steroid use to prevent osteoporosis
Regular low-impact exercise (swimming, stationary bike, yoga) to maintain strength and reduce fatigue without overexertion
Adequate sleep hygiene and stress management as fatigue is common in demyelinating disease
Fall prevention measures at home (remove rugs, install grab bars, adequate lighting) if myelitis-related weakness or gait instability
Influenza and pneumococcal vaccination recommended while on immunosuppression (inactivated vaccines are safe)
Avoid extreme heat exposure (Uhthoff phenomenon: transient worsening of neurological symptoms with elevated body temperature)

differential.features: Short-segment spinal cord lesions; Dawson fingers on MRI; CSF oligoclonal bands positive (>95%); progressive course common; central vein sign on MRI; periventricular/juxtacortical lesions
differential.tests: MRI pattern; CSF OCBs (positive in MS, negative in MOGAD); MOG-IgG negative; AQP4-IgG negative; 7T MRI central vein sign

differential.features: AQP4-IgG positive; area postrema syndrome; longitudinally extensive ON (posterior/chiasmal involvement); worse visual outcomes; predominantly female; non-white ethnicity predilection
differential.tests: AQP4-IgG (positive in NMOSD); MOG-IgG (positive in MOGAD); MRI pattern differences; OCT (worse RNFL loss in AQP4-NMOSD)

differential.features: Monophasic; post-infectious/post-vaccination; large fluffy white matter lesions; MOG-IgG negative; typically pediatric
differential.tests: MOG-IgG testing (many ADEM cases are MOG-IgG positive); clinical course (monophasic vs relapsing)

differential.features: Cranial neuropathies; leptomeningeal enhancement; hypothalamic dysfunction; hilar lymphadenopathy
differential.tests: ACE level; chest CT (hilar adenopathy); biopsy; MOG-IgG negative

differential.features: Mass effect; periventricular enhancement; immunocompromised risk factor; progressive course

differential.tests: Antibody testing; MRI surveillance for MS lesions; serial MOG-IgG retesting

differential.features: AQP4-IgG negative, MOG-IgG negative; clinical phenotype of NMOSD; poor recovery
differential.tests: Both antibody tests negative; clinical/MRI criteria for NMOSD

differential.features: Multifocal stroke-like lesions; headache; elevated inflammatory markers; vessel wall enhancement
differential.tests: Angiography; vessel wall MRI; brain biopsy; ESR/CRP; ANA/ANCA

differential.features: Meningoencephalitis; radial perivascular enhancement; CSF pleocytosis; steroid-responsive
differential.tests: Anti-GFAP antibody (serum and CSF); characteristic radial MRI pattern

differential.features: Granulomatous enhancement; systemic sarcoidosis features; bilateral can occur
differential.tests: ACE; chest imaging; biopsy if needed

differential.features: Fever; infectious prodrome; specific imaging patterns; CSF neutrophilic then lymphocytic
differential.tests: Viral PCR; bacterial/fungal cultures; specific serology

disposition.criteria: Mild symptoms (mild optic neuritis with preserved function); stable or improving on oral steroids; no bladder/bowel dysfunction; able to perform basic ADLs; reliable follow-up within 1-2 weeks; outpatient infusion arranged if IVIG needed; clear understanding of steroid taper schedule

Acute optic neuritis with significant vision loss requiring IV steroids; acute transverse myelitis with weakness or sensory level; ADEM-like presentation requiring workup and IV immunotherapy; need for LP; inability to manage oral medications/self-care

High cervical myelitis with respiratory compromise; severe bilateral optic neuritis with near-complete vision loss; status epilepticus from cortical MOGAD; hemodynamic instability during PLEX; severe encephalopathy (ADEM-like with decreased consciousness)
PLEX not available at current facility; neuroimmunology specialist not available; pediatric case requiring pediatric neurology; need for ICU care exceeding current capabilities
Significant residual weakness from myelitis; gait instability requiring intensive PT/OT; functional deficits preventing safe return home

All patients: neurology follow-up within 1-2 weeks; neuro-ophthalmology within 2-4 weeks if optic neuritis; infusion center for maintenance IVIG; ophthalmology for visual field testing and OCT; PCP for steroid side effect monitoring

New vision loss or worsening visual acuity; new weakness, numbness, or bowel/bladder dysfunction; relapse during steroid taper; severe steroid side effects requiring management; infection while immunosuppressed
